bibl.title: Report to the Secretary of War, by Charles F. Mason, February 17, 1905

div1.p: Mason reports on the Panama Canal Zone Sanitary Department activities with appendices: A - plan of action; B - departmental organization; C - free distribution of quinine.

div1.head: Report to the Secretary of War, by Charles F. Mason, February 17, 1905
div1.opener:
February 17, 1905.
The Honorable Secretary of War,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report that in compliance with your instruction I sailed
from New York for the Isthmus of Panama on January 24th and arrived there Thursday,
February 2d; I again left Panama Thursday, February 9th, having carried out the in-
structions confided to me.

In making this report I shall endeavor, as far as possible, not to go over
again ground which is familiar to you and which is covered by official reports, except
when necessary to elucidate my remarks.

The present condition of health of the canal employes is good; with a total
of about 5000 employes less than 3% are in hospital.

With regard to the present outbreak of yellow fever the following remarks
are submitted:

The statistics regarding yellow fever in the city of Panama prior to Ameri-
can occupation show deaths only as other cases were not reported:

In the first 6 months of 1904 (before American occupation) there were 6 deaths
" " second " " " " (after " " ) " " 13 cases and
three deaths.

In January, 1905, there were 18 cases with 6 deaths (including 2 on the U.S.S. Boston
and 1 in Colon)

Of the total 33 cases, 30 originated in Panama, 3 in Colon.
" " " " " 14 were American, and 11 were Canal employes.

There were no secondary cases, each focus of infection having been promptly
stamped out.

The distribution of the Panama cases showed widely scattered infection:
all the Colon cases originated at one hotel. The three Colon cases occurred on ship-
board, en route to Havana and in the persons of steamer passengers detained at Colon
on account of small-pox; had there been proper detention facilities at that point
these cases should not have occurred.

The cases on the Boston are believed to have been due to a mild and unrecog-
nized case having visited the ship on the occasion of an entertainment given there on
the night of December 31st, which was largely attended by non-immunes from Panama.
Yellow fever mosquitoes were brooding abundantly on the ship and probably became infec-
ted at that time. The fumigation of the ship promptly stopped the outbreak.

While, considering the previous history of Panama in regard to yellow fever,
and the large influx of non-immunes since July first, the number of cases and deaths
has been small, the outbreak becomes important on account of the effect upon public
opinion in relation to the work to be done on the canal.

The sanitary department of the Canal Zone government is subdivided as fol-
lows: A department of hospitals, a maritime quarantine service, a sanitary service
for the Canal Zone, and the health departments of Panama and Colon.
Department of Hospitals.

This includes at present actually in operation the hospitals at Ancon and
Colon and one emergency hospital at Calebra, the three having a total capacity of
254 beds, all of which are occupied. Additional beds are needed, to supply which the
chief sanitary officer has asked for a hundred bed Convalescent hospital at Tuboga
-3-
island, and another hospital of about the same capacity at Miraflorer; the former has
been disallowed for the present, the latter was authorized by Governor Davis about
December 1st, but, through delay in construction and supplies, it is not yet ready for
use. The commission has authorized construction at Ancon and Colon which will give
600 beds, but there is no immediate prospect of the work being done nor any material
or personnel available for utilizing them.

Along the line of the Canal, at convenient points, are stationed four medi-
cal officers with medical supplies, each having charge of a district for emergency
work.among Canal employees.

While the hospital department has about reached the limit of its present
capacity, the sick are well cared for, though for lack of wire screening they are not
adequately protected against malarial infection.
Maritime Quarantine.

At Panama the arrangements while not all that could be desired, are believed
to afford adequate protection against the introduction of quarantinable diseases from
without.

At Colon the arrangements are not so far advanced nor so satisfactory.
Though plans have been approved for a detention building, construction has not been
commenced; the surveillance of detained suspects at hotels, etc., is difficult and
somewhat risky. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, which it is hoped to soon remedy,
it is believed that the quarantine service to date has been effective and that no in-
fectious diseases have been introduced through either port.

Immigration. In this connection the laws of the Canal Zone provide that the
chief quarantine officer shall prevent the entrance to the Zone of any person who is
likely to prove a menace to the public health or welfare or who is likely to become a
-4-
charge upon the public. Nothing however has been actually done under this law to res
strict undesirable immigration.
Sanitary Service of the Canal Zone.

This service, under a Chief Sanitary Inspector, employed on January 31st
about 275 men.

In general it is charged with the duty of cleaning up the settlements of
laborers along the Zone, the removal of night-soil and garbage, surface drainage and
other anti-mosquito work. A great deal of valuable work has been done along the line
but much remains to be done, especially in the matter of screening the dwellings of the
Canal employes and covering their water-barrels with wire gauze. No screening has
been done, and while a large number barrels in some localities have been covered, and
covers prepared for many more, the work is very far from completion because no more
spigots are available to permit the use of the water.
Panama Health Office.

The Chief Sanitary Officer of the Commission has been appointed by the
Republic of Panama, its health officer for the cities of Panama and Colon. In Panama
he has taken charge of the matter of street cleaning, removal of garbage and general
anti-mosquito work on the lines of that carried out in Havana. Just now the whole
city is being fumigated for the destruction of mosquitoes and the work is expected to
be completed by the end of the present month. The cleanliness of the streets, yards
and interior courts has been greatly improved.
Colon Health Office.

Here sanitary work has been confined to garbage removal, a small amount of
street cleaning, and a little oiling of water tanks; the results thus far are not
very apparent, the city being in a very dirty and unsanitary condition.

In Cristobal, however, where most of the Canal employes live, very much more has been
accomplished in the way of surface drainage, removal of garbage and night-soll, anti-
mosquito work, etc.

In making a comparison of sanitary accomplishment with that at Havana in
1901 the differences in condition must be fully understood. In Havana we had a compact
city, with water-works, which had been under American control for more than two years
at the time the anti-mosquito work was begun; which had been thoroughly cleaned; in
which the health and other departments were efficiently organized, and with the Chief
Sanitary Officer possessing complete autonomy in the matter of construction, material
and supplies. In Panama everything was different. The sanitary work had to be done
in two cities, some 50 miles apart and along the intervening strip containing numbers
of native villages. There was no organization anywhere; everything had to be start-
ed. The two cities at either end of the strip were without adequate water supply,
without sewers, without organization of any sort for municipal sanitation, and in an
extremely filthy condition. Being at the very commencement of a vast engineering en-
terprise in which sanitation was only one of the features, it was perhaps natural that
it should receive only what was considered its due share of attention instead of being
the principal feature as at Havana.

Col. Gorgas, the Chief Sanitary Officer, arrived permanently on the Isthmus
and began his work about July 1st last. 1904 The preliminary plan for sanitary work sub-
mitted by him was already in operation to a limited extent. In the months which have
followed much has been accomplished as pointed out under the separate headings.
In Havana in the same period of time yellow fever was wiped out; here it has not been,
though I believe that end will soon be accomplished. In my opinion the diseases
would have been eradicated before this time had it been found practicable to adopt
in its entirety and carry out promptly the scheme proposed by the chief sanitary officer.

The two diseases which more than any others threaten the success of the
Canal project are malaria and yellow fever. While malaria is far more important in
the amount of disease, death and invaliding it is likely to cause on the Isthmus,
yellow fever is no less important in its indirect bearing. While 50 deaths from
malaria might occur without attracting much attention, one-tenth as many from yellow
fever would cause a panicky feeling which would keep any thousands of persons whose
services are needed, or cause them to demand much higher pay for their services.

In the preliminary plan of organization of the sanitary department submitted
in April by Doctors Gorgas, Ross and La Garde, and which in its general features was
approved by the Commission and went into effect in July, 1904, it was proposed to keep
out infectious diseases by a quarantine system, to get in touch with all cases of
malaria and yellow fever by assuming charge of the sick of Panama and Colon and the
Canal strip, to detect them early by a system of inspection, and by screening all acute
cases and keeping others under treatment until they were no longer capable of infecting
mosquitoes, to prevent the spread of these diseases.

On July 26th 1904 the chief sanitary officer, after two months experience as
such, submitted to the Commission a permanent scheme of sanitary organization and read to
the Commission an explanatory statement which I deem of so much importance that it is
hereto appended, marked “A”. In this statement he takes the ground that the cities
of Panama and Colon can and should be freed from yellow fever by January, 1905, and
the Zone from malarial fever in the same period, and before the arrival of the main force
of Canal employes; but that to accomplish such a result he must be able to work more rapid-
ly than was possible with the delay in material, construction, etc., which had occurred
and must occur under the present organization. He further stated that, while the
health conditions on the Isthmus with its present small non-immune population were
about normal, the conditions existed which if not radically changed would in time give
-7-
us the heavy mortality of the French regime. He suggested a remedy in the shape of
greater autonomy with a view to more rapid work, his idea being that the great work
of the sanitary department should be done before the active work began in digging the
Canal. The scheme of organization submitted was an exceedingly able and comprehen-
sive one and if carried out in its entirety would no doubt have accomplished all that
its author hoped for.

To control malaria and yellow fever, besides the general features already
outlined, he provided for treating all the sick of the Canal Zone, and for the admin-
istration of quinine to all those infected with malaria, even though not sick, and
this for both employes and non-employes. This plan, with the anti-mosquito work
would probably have eradicated these diseases. The plan provided for 20 small emer-
gency hospitals with dispensaries attached, and 20 sanitary inspectors with the neces-
sary subordinates, distributed in the villages along the Canal Zone, -the inhabitants
of which were proven to be widely infected with malaria, -and ready to infect, through
the mosquito, the employes of the Canal Commission.

The action taken on this proposed plan and the organization finally adopted
is shown in the Proceedings of the 42d meeting of the Isthmian Canal Commission, dated
August 28, 1904. In a general way the proposed organization was adopted, but
the details were modified in certain very important particulars. The idea of the
Commission seems to have been that conditions should be met as they arose, while the
vital point in the plans of the Chief Sanitary Officer was prevention rather than
cure.

Instead of 20 emergency hospitals and dispensaries, and 20 hospitals along
the Zone, 3 hospitals and dispensaries, 2 additional dispensaries, and 8 Inspectors
were allowed with the proviso for extension when deemed necessary by the Commission.
No reference was made to the plan of treating with Quinine all the inhabitants of the
-8-
Zone infected with malaria, and this recommendation was subsequently disapproved by
the Commission under date of November 5, 1904. On December 21st the Chief Sanitary
Officer explained the importance of this provision in a letter to the Commission in
which he stated that if it was not allowed, his ability to combat malaria would be
reduced one-half.

In regard to assuming complete sanitary control of the cities of Panama and
Colon there were certain legal difficulties of which you know and which were not set-
tled until very recently.

Thus the success of the scheme for the prevention of malaria has been seriously
endangered by doing away with all of its most important features, that of treating
with quinine all persons dangerous to others by harboring the malarial parasites in
the blood. (See Appendix “C”) That part of the scheme which provided for the protection of the canal
employee by screening their dwellings appears to have received no definite action;
nothing has been done toward carrying it into effect.

The defects in the sanitation of the Isthmus then, are, in my opinion, as
follows:-

1. Inadequacy of the scheme for the protection of the Canal employes
against malaria. The scheme as submitted by the chief sanitary officer was adequate,
but its modification by the Commission in cutting off the free issue of quinine, but
authorizing the screening of the dwellings of Canal employes along the strip, and re-
ducing the number of physicians, hospitals and dispensaries along the line has dimin-
ished its value at least one-half.

2. Defective organization of the sanitary department in the lack of suffi-
cient autonomy to carry out its work effectively.

Under the first heading no serious results have followed as yet, but that
they will follow all tropical experiences of like undertakings certainly indicates.

Under the second heading the result has been to greatly delay the work of the sanita-
ry department. Many instances might be quoted; a few will suffice. The principal
large requisition for medicine and medical supplies was made about the first of last
August; at this date, February 8th, not one item has been received. Other large
requisitions made subsequently to this have met the same fate. The Governor, General
Davis, tells me that these requisitions were approved by him and went forward promptly,
and that he has done all in his power to get them filled; what the trouble is he does
not know. Meantime, he has bought what was most urgently needed through the local
markets. Even articles produced in the local market have sometimes required nearly
or quite a month for delivery.

The estimates for repairs to Ancon hospital was made in July last; those
repairs are not yet completed; today, after seven months, only one ward has been
screened. But these points are well covered in the letter of the Chief Sanitary
Officer already referred to as appended and marked “A”.

I think it may be taken as generally accepted that to dig the Canal quickly,
economically and with as little sickness and loss of life as possible it is necessary
that the sanitary work shall be thorough and efficient and shall accomplish results.
If it fails, if the death-rate becomes high, especially for yellow fever, it will in-
crease the cost of the Canal by millions of dollars and delay its completion by years.
I have no doubt that the present small outbreak of yellow fever will add many hundreds
of thousands to the cost of the work and materially delay its construction because
there will be a greater unwillingness to come here, and higher salaries will be de-
manded. There is already apparent a panicky feeling widespread among the employes
and this will be reflected in an exaggerated form in the States. The work of the
Sanitary department is primarily preventive, and only secondarily to meet indications
as they arise; the important part of that work should have been done before the arrival
* Requisition of Dr. La Garde dated Dec. 12/04.
-10-
of the great mass of employes. The defects of the present system and the delays and
imperfections of sanitary accomplishment which have resulted therefrom have been
pointed out in the foregoing pages.

It seems to me that if the work of the sanitary department is to be success-
ful,- and the success of the Canal project depends on it -, the Commission having se-
lected a chief sanitary officer in whom they have confidence should accept his plans
for sanitation as final, give him a free hand and their earnest support in carrying them
out, and hold him strictly responsible for results. What if the chief sanitary of-
ficer does spend $56,000. or $100,000. that could have been saved under a slower and
more restricted method of procedure: The prevention and suppression of epidemic di-
seases often depends upon quick action, and a week's delay may often cost many hun-
dreds of thousands and delay the work of the Canal for long periods. While the
figures show that the rate of sickness among Canal employes is not excessive at pres-
ent, there is no reason to hope that such a condition will continue; on the contrary,
unless the plans of the sanitary department are more quickly and completely carried out
than at present, there is every reason to believe that sickness and mortality will in-
crease as the work goes on and time passes, until health conditions not far different
from those under the French regime will obtain.

In view of the President's message on the subject of the Commission, and
not knowing what the ultimate plan of reorganization may be, I can only make these
broad suggestions as to the work of the sanitary department.

A scheme suggested to the chief sanitary officer and hereto appended, marked
“B” appears to be an excellent one if it can be made to fit into the general plan.
In any case the scheme should be such that measures recommended and requisitions made
by the chief sanitary officer may be acted on promptly and executed without delay.
To effect this it would seem to be necessary that the final authority should reside
-11-
on the Isthmus and not in Washington.

closer.signed:
Sgd C. F. Mason
Major, Surgeon, U. S. Army.

div1.opener:
APPENDIX (A)
Copy of communication of the Chief Sanitary Officer.
Ancon, Isthmian Canal Zone,
July 26, 1904.
Rear Admiral John C. Walker, U. S. N.,
Chairman, Isthmian Canal Commission.
Sir:
div1.p:
I desire to submit the following scheme to the Commission for their con-
sideration:

I have now been the Chief Sanitary Officer of the Commission for two months,
and actively engaged in the organization of my department. In the several informal
conversations I have had with the Commission, I have taken the ground that the towns
of Panama and Colon could be freed from yellow fever, and the strip practically freed
from malarial fever, by July 1905. I had assumed always, in making those statements,
that I could organize and get to work just as rapidly as I, myself, could handle my
material; but in undertaking my work I find that I have to work through other depart-
ments of the Commission, such as the Supply Department, the Engineering Department,
and so on. But from the nature of things those departments are large and extensive,
and their organization will go on slowly. It is not necessary that they be fully
organized until the actual digging of the canal commences. My department is small,
could be organized in a few months; and it is necessary that my work shall have been
completed before that of the others commences. As an illustration: The present
scheme contemplates that the construction of the Sanitary Department be done by the
Engineer Department, and the supplies ordered through the Chief of the Bureau of Ma-
terials and Accounts.

There were certain necessary repairs at Ancon Hospital, that had to be made
before the buildings were occupied. To carry out my idea of the proper care of the
sick, Ancon Hospital should be treating, by Jan. 1st, within the neighborhood of five
hundred patients. The estimates have just been made for these repairs, and the ma-
terial ordered; and it will probably be the 1st of January before those repairs are
anywhere near completion. I had proposed to the Commission to give the sanitary de-
partment a competent engineer. If he had come down with us in April he could have
made all these estimates for the whole department. During May he could have returned
to the United States, ordered all his material, gotten a sufficient personnel together,
and been back on the strip by the 1st of June. By the 1st of July the work could
have been well under way, and by the 1st of October the buildings ready for occupancy.
O do not speak of this in criticism at all; but it is impossible for the Chief Engi-
neer and the Chief of Department of Materials and Accounts to have organized their big
departments so as to meet my emergencies at once; and I have no doubt that two years
from now the Chief Engineer can manage such things much more economically and more ex-
peditiously than I could through my own department. But this system has certainly
up to the present time caused me two months delay; and as I had only about fourteen
months in which to do my work, this has been a very serious loss to me.

Or, take another instance; of my having to work through the Chief of De-
partment of Materials and Accounts. The material which the Commission had authorized
me to buy in New York I was directed, when I arrived, to turn over to the Chief, De-
partment of Materials and Accounts. This was done in accordance with the general
plan adopted by the governor. I make requisition for the spades, bars and special
things which I had bought for special work, in New York. My men are all ready to go
to work and are merely waiting for this material. Two weeks after making the requi-
sition, the things are supplied; but instead of being the things which I had brought
down, they were the old stock of the French company, entirely unsuited for the work;
-3-
and still (a month from the time of my arrival) I have not gotten these things. The
Chief of Materials and Accounts has a large amount of property to distribute, and a
great many regulations, - of which my own is a small part. If I had retained control
of my own property, placed it in a store house and issued it myself, I think my men
could have been at work, as far as tools are concerned, at the end of a week. As I
said before, I have no doubt that two years from now the Chief of this bureau would
have gotten thoroughly organized, and my requisitions would be filled very promptly.
But what will be too late for me. My work will have been either a success or a fail-
ure by that time; and in my opinion some system must be adopted within the next month
or two, which will meet my wants.

And again, with regard to my getting authority from the Governor. As an
illustration: A case of yellow fever occurs in the town of Panama. I have to ask
the Governor's authority for every dollar of expenditures I make. This involves
seeing him every day about two or three points, many of them involving only a few dol-
lars, and unimportant. I consume the Governor's time, although I know every moment
of his time is necessary for important matters of State; and consume my time, which
should be occupied with much more important matters pertaining to the practical work
of my department.

I write a letter to the Governor on this subject, of which I enclose a copy.
The Governor replies, granting the specific things in regard to men, which I ask for.
But the gist of my request, which would have granted me some liberty of action, namely;
that he authorize my expenditure up to $7000 for this purpose, for the succeeding
month, is not granted. I therefore have to go to the Governor in the same way as be-
fore. The next day, the amount of expenditure of $30 or $40 for printing a sanitary
ordinance in this connection comes up. It was not specifically authorized in the
Governor's letter, and I therefore have to go to him about it.

The instances quoted are merely a few among the daily occurrences, that, it
seems to me, are inherent in my position here, namely: being associated with large
departments which necessarily have to be organized slowly, my own department being
small, and the work having to be accomplished before the others commence.

Now, there is no sense in an executive officer pointing out to his superiors
defects, unless he has some suggestion as to remedy. I think it would accomplish my
objects and enable me to organize rapidly and effectively if the Commission would
grant me, for two years, some such scheme as this: That I propose a general plan of
sanitation covering, say, up to July, 1905, going as much as possible into details,
and give items, figures, etc. That the Commission consider this, authorize what they
deem expedient, and then after that, allow me to act freely under this authorization
without further authority from the Governor or Commission. That for every month I
submit to the Commission an estimate of the amount of money needed for that month, for
the running of the department; of course, being governed by the general estimate al-
ready submitted; that this money be placed to the credit of a bonded disbursing offi-
cer of the Sanitary Department; establish a purchasing officer in New York; also a
storehouse on the strip. In this way I think I could obviate delays in getting ma-
terial. As my department expanded, I would want an additional inspector, say.
I see that so many inspectors are authorized by the general scheme. I could communi-
cate with the man, offer him the salary fixed by the Commission and have him at once
placed on my payrolls and put to work; instead of having to go to the Governor, get
the Governor to write to the Commission asking the authority at a certain sum; have
the letter returned from the Commission for some change in the terms allowed, and
finally send to the man to know whether or not he will accept. Or, if it is material
wanted, I could see in the general scheme whether I was authorized to make such pur-
chase; and if I were, write to the Sanitary Department Purchasing Agent in New York,
-5-
have him purchase the goods, ship them at once to the Sanitary Storekeeper and send
the bills to the Sanitary Disbursing Officer. Of course, there would always be
items which cannot be foreseen in my estimate; and these I would have to bring up to
the Governor or to the Commission for authorization; but under my scheme this would
only occur occasionally and would not be a daily affair as it is now.

I would not undertake to make an argument for the necessity of sanitation.
I presume that the Commission accept this. Personally I am more impressed with its
necessity now, than I was two months ago. I see in detail the local causes that
will give us the heavy mortality that the French had, or that occurred during the
days of the railroad construction, unless they are corrected. The inhabitants of the
strip are thoroughly infected with malarial fever, and the conditions of our Marines
and of the American engineers who have so far come in, show that they readily become
infected from these natives. It is evident to anyone, that if you put 15,000 laborers
in the position of these Marines or engineers, they will likewise become infected, and
in the course of time will develop a severe form of malarial fever, as did the French.
The conditions are now, I believe, about the normal state for this tropical locality;
and I have no doubt they were the same a year before the French came here; and our
present knowledge of tropical sanitation makes us certain that two years from now our
mortality will be as heavy as it was two years after the French commenced work, unless
we can radically change conditions.

It is no doubt possible to wait until this mortality begins to show itself,
both in yellow fever and malarial fever, and then take the steps that we see are abso-
lutely necessary. This was done in Havana, and I think could be done here. But a
very much wiser and more economical plan, in my opinion, is to devote the next year to
freeing the Strip, as far as possible, from this malarial infection; to get the towns
along the strip in such condition that when fresh population comes in they will not
-6-
contract malaria from the population already on the ground. Under the present scheme
of administration, I think, the probabilities are that I could do the second; that is,-
by July 1905, get our department in working order so that I could cope with necessi-
ties as they arose; and then, two or three years after that time, get malaria under
control, even with a large laboring population on the ground.

If it were arranged so that I could go on with my organization as rapidly as
I could use my personnel and material, I think that the first could be accomplished,
namely: that by July, 1905, I could get the Strip free from malaria so that the labor-
ing population coming in, would not have the mortality that they will necessarily have
under present conditions.

I do not ask the Commission to change their scheme. I merely ask that I be
temporarily excluded in the points mentioned. As the other departments get organized
I can drop into the general scheme. But if I am to accomplish the work proposed, by
July, 1905, some change which will enable me to act much more expeditiously than I am
at present doing, is absolutely necessary. So far I have carried out, under the di-
rection of General Davis, Governor, the scheme proposed to the Commission in April.
Dr. Carter, as Chief Quarantine Officer, has inaugurated a system of quarantine whereby
infectious and contagious diseases will be kept from coming from the outside. The
President of the Republic, under most liberal decrees, has placed me in entire control
of the quarantine of Panama and Colon; and by another decree, in entire control of
the sanitation of the towns of Panama and Colon. And I would like here to call the
attention of the Commission to the very hearty way in which the President of the Re-
public has cocinded me in every way, in sanitary matters.

Dr. Balch has begun the organization of the Health Department for the city
of Panama; and Dr. Spratling, of the Health Department for the town of Colon.
Dr. Ross, Director of Hospitals, has commenced the organization of the hospitals; and
-7-
Mr. LePrince, Health Officer of the Strip, has commenced his very important work on
the Strip.

I enclose herewith a general estimate of what I think necessary for my de-
partment for the next year. I request that the Commission allow me to appear before
them for the purpose of explaining in detail, this estimate; and for explaining what
to me seems of great importance:- of allowing me greater liberty of action than I at
present possess, and if the necessity of placing my department is such a position that
it can push rapidly forward.

I do not think it necessary that I should have such liberty of action as
this scheme provides, in all the departments for the whole time; for instance:- I can
see very well that the Chief Engineer, from this time on, will do my construction
probably more rapidly and economically that I could do it, and I therefore think it
would be of advantage to the service to leave such work of my department under the
Chief Engineer, as is provided in the present scheme. And so with the other branches.
As I find that I can work with rapidly and efficiency through the other departments
I am perfectly willing to come into the general scheme from time to time.

closer.signed:
Sgd W.C. Gorgas
Ch san Officer

div1.opener:
APPENDIX(B)
Scheme of Organization of the Sanitary Department suggested by the
Chief Sanitary Officer.
div1.p:
The ideal of sanitary organization to my mind, and the best adapted for the
circumstances, is such as we had at Havana: That the Sanitary Department should be an
independent organization just as the Engineers are down here, or the Department of
Material & Supplies, or the Pay Department; and that the Chief Sanitary Officer
should report direct to the supreme authority, without the interference of the Board
of Health, and without the intervention of the Governor. That it should have as-
signed to it its own purchasing officer, its own disbursing officer, and own construct-
ing officer. That the Chief Sanitary Officer should propose a scheme of organization
to this supreme authority, who should adopt such of it as he thought fitted the case:
That for every month the Chief Sanitary Officer should submit a detailed estimate of
the expenses of his department for that month; that the supreme authority should act
upon this estimate; that the sum approved by the supreme authority for that month be
placed to the credit of the disbursing officer of the Sanitary Department and dis-
bursed under the order of the Chief Sanitary Officer according to the approved esti-
mate. With this authority and organization, I am sure I could carry forward the sani-
tation just as we did in Havana. I would then be responsible and could control all
those delays in getting supplies, construction and personnel that have occurred here
and delayed me so much in the sanitation under the Commission. Whatever organization
is adopted for the construction of the canal, it seems to me this is the essential,
as far as the sanitation is concerned: that the Chief Sanitary Officer be held entire
ly responsible for the sanitation, and then be given powers commensurate with this re-
sponsibility. Under the present organization I am nominally responsible, but en-
tirely unable to control, as I am completely dependent upon other departments which,
so far, have been entirely unable to meet my wants.

If the present organization for constructing the canal is continued, the or-
ganization I would urge for the Sanitary Department would be this: That the Chief
Sanitary Officer report directly to the Commission; that in matters which he thought
sufficiently important he could appeal to the Secretary of War, and that the Secretary
of War have the Surgeon General of the Army advise him with regard to such subjects
appealed. That the Commission allow the Sanitary Department a chief of material and
supplies and that this officer be under the orders of the Chief Sanitary Officer, do
all the purchasing and care for all the supplies of the Sanitary Department, just as
the quartermaster of an army post is under the orders of the post commander. That
the Commission appoint for the Sanitary Department an engineer, who shall have charge
and control of all construction under the orders of the Chief Sanitary Officer. That
they appoint for the Sanitary Department a paymaster, who shall do all the disbursing
for the Sanitary Department/ that the Chief Sanitary Officer make monthly estimates to
the Commission, as proposed above. This organization will enable the Chief Sanitary
Officer, after an estimate has been approved for the month, to act freely and promptly
under that estimate and at the same time give the Commission absolute control of the
expenses of the department from the fact that they have to authorize all expenditures.
APPENDIX (C)

The rationale of the free issue of quinine to the native population of the
Canal Zone is as follows:

The malarial infection is due to a microscopic organism which circulates
in the blood of those infected, and when they are bitten by a mosquito of the genus
anopheles the mosquito becomes infected and is probably able to transmit the disease
during the rest of its life.

It has been found that about 70 per cent. of the apparently healthy popu-
lation of the Zone have the malarial infection in their general circulation and so
are active agents in its spread. The routine administration of quinine causes the
malarial parasite to disappear from the blood and no breaks the cycle of the infection,
and thus prevents the native population from being an active source of infection to
the canal employes. It is a preventive measure of primary importance.
